content:
Nice challenge, I agree with ManuelJ that restricting this to just Shortest is a shame.

Also, your Constraints section currently says:
- line is not longer than 100 characters

but none of your tests or validators exceed 16 characters. It would be good to update this constraint to better reflect the actual tests, as otherwise it might lead people to avoid brute force methods (like simply producing an array of every substring and then checking which ones are unique afterwards).

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: idk why only game mode is sorted... fastest might be good also. anyways good puzzle.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: accepting

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Okay... Iâ€™ll most probably lose the Shortest Mode with my code ðŸ˜­. Still, it was a fun question. Glad to see something like this out here â€” it really makes you think.

b=[]
def S(l):
    s=''
    for i in range(len(l)):
        if l[i] not in s:s+=l[i]
        elif s not in b:b.append(s);s=''
        else:s=''
    if s not in b:b.append(s)
l=input()
for i in range(len(l)):S(l[i:])
b.sort(key=lambda x:l.find(x))
v=max(b,key=lambda x:len(x))
print(v,len(v))
https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-substring-without-repeating-characters/description/

Goal
* The task is confusing. There's nothing "non-consecutive" about the output - I think you're trying to say something else. Please rewrite the task.

* Please remove the examples.

Input
* Please delete the first sentence.

* Please change "Line" to "Line 1".

* Please change "parsed" to "processed".

Goal / Input / Constraints
* Please change "[[string]]" to "[[line]]" for consistency with the stub generator.

Constraints
* Please mention that [[line]] always contains more than one unique character.

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback. All very good points, I have updated the task, with one exception. the last constraint, as a string consisting of only one character would be valid.
Thanks
Thanks
Thanks, I thought I had too choose one mode.
Thanks, I thought I had too choose one mode.

Ahh, yeah you can check all three boxes if you like, you've got to a bit careful with Reverse mode since sometimes it's just too hard to figure it out, but this one looks suitable for all three, I think.

Ah, you're right. I was misled by the now-deleted examples. Sorry about that.

Input
* Please change "[[string]]" to "[[line]]".

Cases
* It looks like Validator 4 is the only case where the rule "If multiple solutions are possible, return the first longest sequence found" is invoked. If so, please add one more pair of cases where the rule applies.

Thanks.

Yes, you are right. It was hidden in the longer examples: ABACDEFAB, here BACDEF is possible, as well as CDEFAB and a few other solutions.

But It is better to add an explicit test case for this, so the coder can understand the problem.
Many thanks for your quick follow-up!

I thank you for the feedback. This is my first contribution - still learning how the platform works. Like StackOverflow, there are certain unwritten rules, that everyone expects. Which are required and improve the experience ;)
Hope you enjoy your stay and learn something useful here!
Thanks, having a lot of fun so far, especially clash of code - quick, whenever you have 5min.
I've had another thought about this clash - are we missing cases like PPPPPQQRRRRSSSTT and UUUVVVXXXYYYZZZ?

That's a good point. The cases I chose were meant to be easy for the coder to understand. Just by looking at them, you can quickly get the longest sequence. The ones you posted above are a lot harder to do manually, especially with time pressure.

But it makes sense to add them as an additional test case. Is being overly specific a thing, to allow crazy solutions, or is it better to be very precise in all edge cases?

I will add your proposed test cases, unless you disagree.
Sure, I have no problem with that ðŸ™‚
